subs.text:
@mustin_burt @JMiguel_daniels @DannyJasso7 @POTUS That should be a mostly fixed price per gallon, though, not a percentage.

(except that gasoline delivery tanker trucks still use inflated-cost diesel fuel, so there is an intrinsic feedback loop that will always tend to cause short-term increases quicker than decreases)

subs.text:
@AlexandraDixon @IlyaMatveev_ As of last July, 25% was foreign-owned, with the top four nations holding:
    (in trillions of USD)
  $1.3 - Japan
  $1.1 - China
  $0.5 - United Kingdom
  $0.3 - Ireland

(… followed by Luxembourg, Cayman Islands, Taiwan, Brazil, Hong Kong, and France, each with > $0.2 T)

2/
subs.rawText:
@AlexandraDixon @IlyaMatveev_ As of last July, 25% was foreign-owned, with the top four nations holding:
    (in trillions of USD)
  $1.3 - Japan
  $1.1 - China
  $0.5 - United Kingdom
  $0.3 - Ireland

subs.text:
@AlexandraDixon @IlyaMatveev_ 53% was domestically-owned, including:
    (trillions of USD)

  $9.8 - Domestic (US) investors (non-government)
  $5.3 - US Federal reserve

The remaining 22% was owned by actual US Gov. sources (e.g. ‘Social Security trust fund’, DoD pension funds, gov’t pension funds)

3/4

subs.text:
@micro_cabbage (Twitter is acting up right now; didn’t intend to reply to your photo of the TRIDENT capsules??)

I was referring to the possible re-use of ICBM-style tech on the Iskander systems; agreeing with your comment that it seemed overly complex for the mission. Then again, it’s working.

subs.text:
@micro_cabbage If you realize that your internal (secret) doctrine is that you may threaten nuclear strikes from time to time but never actually be dumb enough to launch them, then that kind of technology re-use isn’t really risking anything at all.

(Esp. with NATO THAAD/‘Aegis Ashore’ panic)

subs.text: March 15

@micro_cabbage @GrumpyBadger5 @atomicthumbs @lucky_591008 @CAT_UXO Why innovate when you can just re-use something previously developed/tested for a more complex missile system?

(Anything developed in the current, apparently corrupt, defense environment risks realization as the proverbial  ‘bomb casing filled with used pinball machine parts’.)
subs.rawText:
@micro_cabbage @GrumpyBadger5 @atomicthumbs @lucky_591008 @CAT_UXO Why innovate when you can just re-use something previously developed/tested for a more complex missile system?

subs.text:
@GrumpyBadger5 @StretchJourno @CAT_UXO A thread elsewhere suggested these are likely re-used from nuclear-armed versions of the missiles, so a decades-old design might make sense.

There even could be overlap with decoys used with their ICBMs… why re-invent the wheel if you’ve already got something in production?
subs.rawText:
@GrumpyBadger5 @StretchJourno @CAT_UXO A thread elsewhere suggested these are likely re-used from nuclear-armed versions of the missiles, so a decades-old design might make sense.

There even could be overlap with decoys used with their ICBMs… why re-invent the wheel if you’ve already got something in production?

subs.text: “Discussing how #Russia is governed we talk a lot about politics, ideology, religion. And yet, we pay too little attention to the economy of power. Russian regimes typically focus on two tasks: 1Producing tradable goods (=raw materials) 2Exporting them” #history #Muscovy [link]
subs.rawText:
“Discussing how #Russia is governed we talk a lot about politics, ideology, religion. And yet, we pay too little attention to the economy of power.

Russian regimes typically focus on two tasks:
1Producing tradable goods (=raw materials)
2Exporting them”

#history #Muscovy https://t.co/zO5m6A1Ihp

subs.text: March 13

@Lifaccordng2kat @juliaioffe Industrial demand is the most significant.

For individuals with the option, for example, perhaps:
 
- fewer discretionary driving vacations (or vacations closer to home)

- carpooling to work

- leaving / later earlier to avoid traffic

- using a more fuel-efficient vehicle

subs.text: March 8

@WildGoo69031318 @juliaioffe We’re not importing gas, though, we’re importing oil.

Any effects will be spread against all users of the refined products, and more elastic end-users (e.g. aluminum smelters) will likely cause prices to stabilize before actions by more inelastic gasoline users.
subs.rawText:
@WildGoo69031318 @juliaioffe We’re not importing gas, though, we’re importing oil.

Any effects will be spread against all users of the refined products, and more elastic end-users (e.g. aluminum smelters) will likely cause prices to stabilize before actions by more inelastic gasoline users.

@RonWenig @ThordaksMommy @mehdirhasan @iterorg @fusionforenergy @mit_nse @CFS_energy Apparently starting a #fusion rx is relatively solved… getting new fuel in and used ‘ash’ out of a running reactor is one of the biggest challenges #ITER hopes to help solve.

2045 could be possible, if proper resources were applied, but I wouldn’t wager any magic beans on that.

@constanceshortc @Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @Bundeskanzler There were reports from over a week ago, during the first nights of the evacuation: separation of those with Ukrainian passports and those without (due to EU migration rules).

Fixed 1 day later when the entire EU agreed to allow visa for anyone who had been living in Ukraine…

subs.text:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler I’ve read that Germany currently has several _months_ of natural gas reserves; 1/5 of that may be controlled by a Russian-owned company, 

… but that still gives them plenty to survive the winter / springtime, at _current_ usage levels, assuming _zero_ foreign gas imports.

subs.text:
@Heykki80 @jmkorhonen @constanceshortc @Bundeskanzler … and in any case, if supply was somehow constrained, it’s not domestic heating that would be blocked first but rather energy supply for factories / industry.

So, there are likely significant corporate interests in keeping energy cheap. Follow the money.

subs.text:
@MSzafranski413 @DanLamothe Keep in mind someone saying they “cannot corroborate” something doesn’t mean they can’t have detailed confirmed intelligence on a topic.

Not having permission to corroborate something can also result in that response, and the IC will ultimately share only what it wants to share.
subs.rawText:
@MSzafranski413 @DanLamothe Keep in mind someone saying they “cannot corroborate” something doesn’t mean they can’t have detailed confirmed intelligence on a topic.

Not having permission to corroborate something can also result in that response, and the IC will ultimately share only what it wants to share.

subs.text: @mairtinofaolain @cormacleane @evangershkovich From what little I’ve read, yes, these sorts of markings are indeed temporary and meant to be applied immediately prior to a battle - ostensibly to maximize (visual) IFF ability and minimize chances for enemy spoofing.

@cormacleane @mairtinofaolain @evangershkovich Unverified:

V - Marines
Z - Eastern Military District
Z in a square - Southern Military District (Crimea)
O - units from Belarus
X - forces of Ramzan Kadyrov, Putin installed warlord of Chechnya 
A - Russian Special Forces(SSO) (e.g. Spetznaz)

subs.text:
@aydincalik90 @shadihamid It’s the nuclear weapons.

Letting Russia get away with this sort of thing only strengthens the logical/strategic case for nations like Iran to continue to rapidly develop new weapons and for the DPRK, India, France, Pakistan, Israel, etc. to maintain their current inventories.

subs.text: March 1

@markproxy Reminds me of something recently read in a Corey book:

“There is nothing in that message. Nothing. He is walking around his words like they’ve got poisoned spikes on them. And what’s he got? Threats. No one makes threats.”
